summary: On October 5, 2018, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment against Michael Deline in a domestic-relations case.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Little Rock, Arkansas, alleges that Michael was found in contempt for violating the court's orders to impose a temporary restraining order on his ex-wife, Jaime Deline, and her son, Douglas Deline.  According to the complaint, Michael's visitation was limited to Saturday and Sunday from 10:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m., based on his income of $5,000 per month.  Michael also alleges that on the morning of the second day of the trial, Michael had a "near syncope" event on his way to court, causing him to almost crash his vehicle.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Arkansas today announced criminal charges against Michael.  On October 13, the court granted Michael's motion for a continuance and ordered him to pay $2,178 for unpaid child support, $9,526.76 for spousal support, and $10,800 in attorney's fees.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Michael consented to the entry of the final judgment, which permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders Michael to comply with the court order and pay $1,114.89 a month or $257.48 a week in court-ordered child support and a $13,549.48 interest at the rate of 10% per annum, for a total of $17,549,48, together with an interest at a rate of 9% per year, for Michael and Jaime's joint account of $192,829.95.   The court also ordered Michael to remove any evidence that he had provided to the court concerning his violation of the court orders, including that Jaime had provided corroborating testimony to corroborate Michael's claims in the complaint.  Additionally, Michael was ordered to remove all firearms and other weapons while EA was present for visitation; and did not prohibit Michael from photographing or videotaping EA "in the ordinary course of being a parent" but prohibited him from posting any "photos, videos, audio or any other matter, involving the minor child, the parties, the attorneys, the Court, or anything having to do with this matter" on social media.  Finally, Michael agreed to be permanently enjoined from associating with any person who has prejudgment interest in
